{"step_by_step_thinking": "Dental caries and periodontal disease are both oral health problems. Dental caries, or cavities, are caused by the acid produced by bacteria in the mouth, which erodes the tooth enamel. Periodontal disease, on the other hand, is a gum disease that can lead to tooth loss. It is caused by bacteria in the mouth that infect the tissues around the teeth. The common factor in both these diseases is the presence of bacteria in the mouth, which forms a bacterial plaque. Lactic acid is a byproduct of bacterial metabolism but not all bacteria produce it. Calculus, or tartar, is hardened plaque and is a secondary factor, not the initiating factor.
